prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: As has been stated earlier, confidential business information is information that has been developed through the employer's expenditure of effort, time, labour and resources. That is what gives information its commercial quality. Where former employees can demonstrate that information was developed subsequently through their own efforts, capital and time, or based upon information in the public domain, the courts will generally not interfere with their activities.

In the often cited case of Molnar Lithographic Supplies Ltd. v. Sikatory,[1] the court found that the employer had failed to establish that a former employee had obtained knowledge of the ingredients of a formula solely from the employer. Rather, the employee had, by trial and error, used various trade publications, books and publicly available information to develop a similar formula on his own. On appeal, the decision of the trial court was upheld on the same principle.[2]

On the other hand, where the court is convinced that the information did come from the employer, the former employee will likely be held accountable. This was the key basis on which the court in Belform Insulation Ltd. v. Toleks Insulation Ltd.[3] granted a permanent injunction. Specifically, the court concluded that the employee would never have been able to produce the coverings in question using only publicly available information. Even someone “skilled in the art or science” would not have been able to do so.[4] Significantly, the judge noted that there was no evidence that any other manufacturer employed the same production processes in making a similar product.[5]

The courts may shift the demarcation between confidential information and the employee's skills and knowledge where the information in question was produced by the employee. For example, in Delrina Corp. v. Triolet Systems Inc.,[6] the court held that, in the circumstances, the information at issue should be considered to be part of the employee's own working knowledge and skill:

[When] the subject matter of the trade secret is brought into being because of the initiative of the employee in its creation, innovation or development even though the relationship is one of confidence, no duty arises since the employee may then have an interest in the subject matter at least equal to that of his employer or in any event, such knowledge is a part of the employee's skill and experience.

In Shaver-Kudell Manufacturing Inc. v. Knight Manufacturing Inc.,[7] the Plaintiff SK operated a machine shop which manufactured metal sleeves of different lengths and diameters, which are used to repair the ball bearings in electric motors. SK claimed that the tooling and manufacturing process that it developed to make the metal sleeves were trade secrets that were confidential in nature and alleged that the Defendants misappropriated its trade secrets and that the employee committed a breach of confidence in relation to SK's tooling, manufacturing process and customer list.[8]

Lucy was SK's first employee. Over the course of 23 years, she had regular contact with customers and held many roles within the company, including customer service and marketing. Towards the end of her employment, she was also responsible for shipping and receiving. In that role, she had familiarity with SK customer orders. As the employee responsible for accounts receivable, she also had familiarity with customers' credit status. When Lucy left the family business and within months joined KM as a telemarketer, these customers remembered her. She immediately re-connected with customers she had interacted with for two decades. In doing so, she reported to Mr. Knecht and Mr. Ballmer that customers recognized her as “Lucy from SK”. Lucy relied on her knowledge of SK's customers to solicit them to follow her to KM. Many of these customers followed her and transferred their business to KM.[9]

The definition of a “trade secret” includes “a plan or process, tool … known only to its owner and those of his employees to whom it is necessary to confide it”. Therefore, a tool or manufacturing process can be a trade secret provided it meets other requirements.[10]

To decide if SK's manufacturing process it developed to make metal sleeves were trade secrets, SK was required to prove that: (1) The [manufacturing process it used to make metal sleeves were specific and not of general public knowledge; (2) Its manufacturing process used to make sleeves were only known by SK and the required employees; and (3) SK demonstrated an intention to treat its manufacturing process confidential.[11]

Justice Smith accepted the evidence of the plaintiff's expert that the manufacturing process developed by SK was different from a well-known process. SK developed their manufacturing process over 20 years and received research grants over that period of over 2 million dollars to develop the new tools and manufacturing process. The defendant KM did not provide any technical drawings showing an independent path of development and in less than 9 months developed the same tools and used the same manufacturing process as SK had developed. These facts supported an inference that KM copied SK's tooling and manufacturing process to make sleeves. KM used the identical sleeve size and parts list that was used by SK. The outside diameter of industrial sleeves produced by KM were identical to those of SK which was also “beyond coincidence”.[12]
Justice Smith accepted the expert evidence that the manufacturing process of making sleeves developed by SK were unique and was a new method which was unknown to the public.[13]

Justice Smith observed that in Saltman Engineering Co. v. Campbell Engineering Co. (1948), 65 R.P.C. 203 (C.A.), the court held that the necessary quality of confidence has been interpreted to mean that the information is not public property or public knowledge and that the author of the trade secret used his brain to produce a result. Here Neil Shaver used his brain to develop a new manufacturing process and new tooling to produce sleeves which were unknown to the public or to any competitors, before KM used the same process. The expert witness testified that the process was not described in the Handbook and was a process and tooling that was unknown to the public. The decision in R.L. Crain Ltd. v. R.W. Ashton & Ashton Press Manufacturing Co., relied on by the Defendants, was distinguished on the following basis: (a) In RL Crain there were “many other” processes like the one at issue on the market, which was not the case for the tooling SK used to make sleeves; (b) In RL Crain the Plaintiff sought to prevent the Defendants from operating a business that did not operate against their own. Here, KM was in direct competition with SK selling exactly the same product; and (c) The product in RL Crain was an upgraded version of a product that was commercially available. Justice Smith observed that there was a fundamental difference between the finished product, namely the sleeve on the market, and the tooling and manufacturing process used to make the product being on the market. The sleeve product was public but the tooling and manufacturing process used to manufacture the sleeves was confidential.[14]

Justice Smith concluded that the manufacturing process and the tooling developed by SK were trade secrets and had the necessary quality of confidence and cited Stonetile (Canada) Ltd. v. Castcon Ltd., 2010 CarswellAlta 1073, 2010 ABQB 392, where the court set out seven factors to consider to determine if the information has the necessary quality of confidence, stating:

(b) Neil's evidence that no other company in the world makes sleeves in this manner was uncontradicted; and;
(c) SK's manufacturing process was not described in the Handbook and Mr. Cashion's evidence, which I accepted, was that this process was not known outside of SK's business;

paratext.bold: (2) Extent to which it is known by employees and others in the business

para.paratext: (a) Neil testified that only SK's employees knew about his [text omitted] manufacturing process [text omitted] and his evidence was not contradicted;

(b) Lucy acknowledged that SK's manufacturing process and the [text omitted] was confidential to SK and she followed the warning on the bottom of SK's custom order computer screens that said [text omitted] and;
(c) I accept Mr. Cashion's evidence that SK's manufacturing process and [text omitted] were unknown to others in the business.
(a) Only SK employees had access to the production floor. There is signage on the doors leading to the shop to that effect;
(b) Visitors did not have access to the production floor and were restricted to the office area of the facilities;
(c) The Plaintiff's facility is equipped with a security system;
(d) Each employee had their own security code to access the facilities after hours;
(e) SK's technical and financial information was stored on the Plaintiff's secured computer network, which was not connected to the internet;

(f) SK had reminders on the computer screens saying never to mention [text omitted] to customers. Below this warning is a note that indicates [text omitted] This was a deliberate attempt by Shaver-Kudell to protect the use of [text omitted] to make sleeves [text omitted]

(h) Mr. Shaver personally escorted any visiting delegation throughout the facility. Prior to any such visit, employees hid the tooling, and the [text omitted] They also covered the [text omitted] to ensure that their operations remained confidential.

paratext.bold: (4) Value of the information of the holder

para.paratext: (a) The manufacturing of sleeves to repair electric motors is a niche market;
(b) There are only 3 sleeve manufacturers worldwide and only SK and KM use the same manufacturing process and tooling;
(c) There is increased efficiency and cost savings in using the manufacturing process developed by SK [text omitted]

SK has spent over $2 million developing the [text omitted] manufacturing process and [text omitted] that were required.

paratext.bold: (6) Ease with which information can be acquired or duplicated

para.paratext: (a) Only two companies in the world, SK and KM, use the [text omitted] manufacturing process developed by SK;
(b) SK has used the manufacturing process since 1988;
(c) Mr. Coles, the Defendants' expert, agreed that the similarities of the outside diameters of KM sleeves with those of SK were “past coincidence”;
(d) It would not be easy to develop the same manufacturing process and [text omitted] without copying the ideas from SK.

paratext.bold: (7) Whether the holder and taker of the secret treat it as secret

para.paratext: (a) Both parties including KM take the view that their manufacturing process and tooling are proprietary, confidential and secret.[15]

Justice Smith observed that in Coco v. A.N. Clark (Engineers) Ltd., [1969] R.P.C. 41 (Eng. Ch. Div.), the Court held that an objective test should be applied to determine if the confidential information was communicated in confidence. Justice Smith concluded that that a reasonable person in the shoes of Lucy would have realized that the information acquired about SK's manufacturing process was acquired in confidence. Lucy was a long term trusteed employee of SK. Lucy knew or ought to have known that SK's manufacturing process was confidential information. As a result of Lucy being one of SK's key employees over 23 years, which included the period when the manufacturing process and tooling were developed, Lucy was aware of SK's manufacturing process. While Lucy worked primarily in the office area, she had full access to the manufacturing facility and while not a machinist, she was aware of the manufacturing processes used in the shop.[16]

Justice Smith did not accept that the defendants developed the same manufacturing process and tooling to make sleeves as SK independently. No plans or drawings were produced to show an independent development process. The defendants had plenty of opportunity to observe SK's tooling and manufacturing process, because the defendants had regular access to SK's facility and because Lucy knew about them. The similarity of the manufacturing process and the tooling that he used with that of SK was beyond coincidence.[17]

SK never waived its right to preserve the use of the confidential information related to its manufacturing process and tooling for its own benefit when it allowed Lucy, as a trusted employee, to become aware of it. Justice Smith observed that in Wodehouse Invigorator Ltd. v. Ideal Stock & Poultry Food Co., 1917 CarswellOnt 212, [1917] O.J. No. 234 (C.A.), the court held that an employer, who permits an employee to acquire full knowledge of a trade secret without stipulation, is not considered to have waived their right to preserve the secret for his or her benefit.[18]

The Defendants committed a breach of confidence and misappropriated SK's trade secrets concerning its manufacturing process because the information the Defendants acquired had the necessary quality of confidence, the information was communicated to or acquired by Lucy in circumstances giving rise to an obligation of confidence, that SK's trade secrets were communicated to KM who knew or ought to have known that Lucy was breaching an obligation of confidence to SK and the Defendants had made unauthorized use of SK's trade secrets to its detriment.[19]
